metadata.h1: Analysing live News stream on Google cloud

all_paragraphs: Natural language processing has many interesting applications. Here we will take a look at processing live newswire to derive sentiment from news articles and applying them against geo and organisation level tags. This approach can be extended to enrich econometric data to predict the ongoing market pulse, public emotion and its potential impact.
There are a number of news and media streaming API available which provides live streaming content.
One of the content-rich is The New York Times developer program. It offers several ways to access the news articles; here is a glimpse of all it has to offer on the catalogue.
We will be looking at Times Wire API feed; it streams up-to-the-minute articles as soon as they are published on NYTimes.com.
You can register yourself to access the stream and generate API key at https://developer.nytimes.com/accounts/create
Here is what the news streaming content looks like (df_page), we will be analysing title and abstract columns.

NLP has been around for long. Leveraging Google’s powerful text analysis algorithms is very straight forward on GCP. Google Cloud Natural Language API — it is a set of powerful machine learning models in the cloud. It provides the ability to do Sentiment Analysis, Entity Analysis, Syntax Analysis, Entity Sentiment Analysis and Text Classification without any labelled or training data. These models are pre-trained with relatively large datasets, so the user does not need to train the dataset and can straight away start using it.
The Natural Language API comprises of five different services:

Sentiment Analysis: It estimates emotional opinion within the text evaluating how positive, neutral, or negative the content is. It returns sentiment scores ranging between -1.0(negative) and 1.0 (positive). It also returns a magnitude score starting at 0 and reaching to infinity; this indicates the overall strength of emotion. These scores are given to the entire document as well as individual sentences.

Entity Analysis: It tries and identify known entities (proper nouns) within the provided text and returns additional information about it. Identified entities are given a salience score (of 0.0 to 1.0), which reflects their relevance to the overall document. Such entities are then tagged by type, ex: Person, Location, Organization.
Syntax Analysis:Syntax Analysis inspects the language structure and breaks up the given text into sentences and tokens, which then outputs linguistic analysis information.
Entity Sentiment Analysis:This combines the outcome provided by Sentiment analysis and Entity Analysis to show the sentiment estimated at the entity level within the text.
Text Classification:Categories the corpus into one of the pre-defined categories ex: Art, Business, Health, Science, etc.
